contentfulBlogPost.title: Something Is Wrong with Testing Data in the Great State of Texas

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Judith Oppenheim works on Texas City Data and state outreach at The COVID Tracking Project.
Pat Kelly is a technology executive and entrepreneur based in Austin, Texas, and works on The COVID Racial Data Tracker and The Long-Term Care COVID Tracker at The COVID Tracking Project.
Madhavi Bharadwaj is a data driven creative thinker and lifelong learner who is passionate about healthcare and public health.
Lauran Hazan is a product management leader with a minor data obsession. Currently in the Boston area on a new startup adventure.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: How Probable Cases Changed Through the COVID-19 Pandemic

lede.lede: When analyzing COVID-19 data, confirmed case counts are obvious to study. But don’t overlook probable cases—and the varying, evolving ways that states have defined them.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jonathan Gilmour is a Data Infrastructure engineer and Data Quality contributor at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: 20,000 Hours of Data Entry: Why We Didn’t Automate Our Data Collection

lede.lede: Looking back on a year of collecting COVID-19 data, here’s a summary of the tools we automated to make our data entry smoother and why we ultimately relied on manual data collection.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: A Wrap-Up: The Five Major Metrics of COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project comes to a close, here’s a summary of how states reported data on the five major COVID-19 metrics we tracked—tests, cases, deaths, hospitalizations, and recoveries—and how reporting complexities shaped the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing Our State COVID-19 Data Log

lede.lede: From July 2020 to March 2021, The COVID Tracking Project compiled a detailed set of structured COVID-19 data notes, both on changes states made to the data and changes we made to the data we captured from states. Today, we’re releasing those notes.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Entered COVID-19 Testing and Outcomes Data Every Day for a Year

lede.lede: We set up a set of roles and a shift system to carefully gather and inspect the data we published.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID-19 Testing Data Is Getting Better

lede.lede: The federal government improved its state and county-level COVID-19 PCR testing data since we analyzed it in February. Here’s an update on those changes and what we hope to see next for the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Inconsistent Reporting Practices Hampered Our Ability to Analyze COVID-19 Data. Here Are Three Common Problems We Identified.

lede.lede: With little consistency in how states defined, published, and presented COVID-19 data, it is difficult to compare situations across states.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: A New Surge Has Arrived in Michigan, but We Don’t Know What It Will Look Like

lede.lede: According to federal data, COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations have reversed their decline in Michigan, marking a new surge concentrated in and around Detroit, but affecting regions statewide.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing our Annotations on COVID-19 State Data Definitions

lede.lede: As part of our wind-down process, we’re publicly sharing our structured metadata on state COVID-19 data definitions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.

blog_post.title: Giving Thanks and Looking Ahead: Our Data Collection Work Is Done

lede.lede: While our work to compile COVID-19 data has concluded, we will continue to share research, analysis, and documentation in the months ahead. We are enormously grateful to the hundreds of volunteers who made this work possible.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data

lede.lede: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. Here’s a little about where that data comes from, what each dataset has to offer, and how you can use the datasets best in light of their large differences from state-provided data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How Day-of-Week Effects Impact COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: An understanding of state reporting schedules and day-of-week effects can help explain the reasons that numbers fluctuate from day to day, and what those changes mean.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal Testing Data’s Last Mile

lede.lede: Federal testing data is already more standardized and more detailed than the data we compile from states can ever be. But in some jurisdictions, state-provided data still provides a more comprehensive picture of testing volume. The federal government should address lingering quality problems so its data can become the national standard.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Silent Data Mismatches Are Compromising Key COVID-19 Indicators

lede.lede: Although we’d prefer to have precise, real-time, comprehensive COVID-19 data for every US state and territory, the reality is that every metric that each jurisdiction publishes comes with quirks of timing and content that can make precise calculations impossible.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Michael Parks is a journalist and communications specialist with a background in energy research and policy.
Nicole Rivera is a policy and public affairs professional who has focused on developing creative and strategic ways to communicate complex issues with clarity.

blog_post.title: Better COVID-19 Data Is Coming By August 1—But Will the Public See It?

lede.lede: Starting in August, new federal rules will require testing labs to report better data on the spread of COVID-19 in the United States. What happens to this new information is up to state and local officials. Journalists, open-data advocates, and members of the public can help us hold governments accountable for collecting and publishing this urgently needed data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

lede.lede: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters

lede.lede: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Counting COVID-19 Tests: How States Do It, How We Do It, and What’s Changing

lede.lede: Many states have moved toward greater transparency about their test data reporting methods, and we’re making changes to better represent what they publish. We’re also introducing a “new” way some states are counting tests—one we think all states and territories would be wise to embrace.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Test Types 101: The Pros and Cons of Different Approaches

lede.lede: Once limited to molecular tests, the United States now has other testing methods available. Their efficacy depends on multiple factors, including how far the person tested is in their infection and how high the test positivity is where they live.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Cases Matter

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases rise across the United States, claims are circulating that case increases are (mostly or entirely) due to expanded testing, and do not indicate a spike in infections. The data does not support this conclusion.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.
Michal Mart is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Good News about Florida’s Testing Data

lede.lede: Florida is now publishing a full time series of test encounters, so we are picking up this metric in our API and on our website.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Daily COVID-19 Data Is About to Get Weird

lede.lede: The upcoming holiday means that many COVID-19 metrics are going to drop—and then rise—in ways that may trip up unsuspecting observers. Here’s what to watch out for.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.

blog_post.title: What We Know About Covid Testing Sensitivity

lede.lede: To successfully manage the pandemic, we need tools for both surveillance and diagnosis, in the form of antigen tests and PCR tests.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Ultralight Recommendations for a National Pandemic Dashboard

lede.lede: The announcement of a forthcoming national pandemic dashboard is heartening news for COVID-19 data folks all over the country. We have a few modest suggestions for the team that will undertake this work.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Tong Wang is an MD-PhD candidate at the University of Pennsylvania.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.

blog_post.title: The Other COVID-19 Metric We Should Be Using

lede.lede: As exposure risk increases, so does the need for more testing. The more we test, the more cases we can identify—which is a good thing. But are we looking at the right metrics to know if we are performing enough tests?

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: It's Not Just Testing

lede.lede: As case counts surge, we look at regional and state-level numbers to find out which recent jumps in COVID-19 case counts are likely to be explained by increased testing, and which are not. For the states with the worst recent numbers, the news is not good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Test Positivity in the US Is a Mess

lede.lede: Interpreted correctly, test positivity can tell us so much that we need to know about COVID-19 outbreaks and testing in the United States. But we don’t publish test positivity calculations for US states and territories. Here’s why.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: The State of State Antigen Test Reporting

lede.lede: Antigen tests are becoming a major tool for rapid COVID-19 testing. But if states don’t report results clearly, we won’t know the true impact of these tests.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Tong Wang is an MD-PhD candidate at the University of Pennsylvania.

blog_post.title: Test Positivity: So Valuable, So Easy to Misinterpret

lede.lede: Test positivity is extremely useful, but it has also become one of the most commonly misunderstood metrics for monitoring the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we take a step back and look at what it really means.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10

lede.lede: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.

blog_post.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3

lede.lede: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Judith Oppenheim works on Texas City Data and state outreach at The COVID Tracking Project.
Pat Kelly is a technology executive and entrepreneur based in Austin, Texas, and works on The COVID Racial Data Tracker and The Long-Term Care COVID Tracker at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Something Is Wrong with Testing Data in the Great State of Texas

lede.lede: According to the official state numbers, COVID-19 testing has dropped dramatically in August. However, county-level statistics show the opposite story. What’s going on?

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Tests, Cases, and Hospitalizations Keep Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 13

lede.lede: Testing continues to fall, especially in the South, one of the areas where the country needs it the most. Cases, too, are falling, which remains hard to interpret, given the testing decline—but fewer people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than last week. This is the second week in a row that hospitalizations seem to have dropped, which suggests that infections may be declining independently of testing reductions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Emma Rubin is a recent college graduate and freelance journalist.

blog_post.title: Florida’s Per-Capita COVID-19 Cases Just Surpassed New York’s, but Are the Two Outbreaks Comparable? Yes and No.

lede.lede: Florida has reported over 461,000 total COVID-19 cases, surpassing New York for the highest per-capita caseload in the United States—but a simple comparison doesn’t represent the critical differences in the data we have for the two outbreaks.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

lede.lede: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.

blog_post.title: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 2: Across the US, Outbreaks Are Catching Fire

lede.lede: The US has broken its record for new COVID-19 cases three times in the last week. Thirteen states broke their new-case records since Sunday. In the states with the worst outbreaks, hospitalizations and deaths are rising.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 25: The US Pandemic Is Surging in the South and West

lede.lede: The United States hit a record high for new COVID-19 cases this week. In many areas with rising case counts, testing isn’t keeping up. Meanwhile, hospitalizations in regions with big outbreaks are increasing.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 18: The Regional Gap Widens

lede.lede: As cases and hospitalizations continue to drop in the early Northeast epicenters, they are rising—in some areas quite sharply—in the South and West. We look at the numbers and at the relationship between an increase in tests and a rise in case counts.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 11: Early Data from May Transmission

lede.lede: The news this week is mixed and highly regional. In the early US epicenter of the outbreak, cases continue to drop. In the southern and western United States, cases are on the rise, as are COVID-19 hospitalizations. And as always, the lag makes the data difficult to put into context.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: What Is a Probable Case of COVID-19?

lede.lede: Probable cases of COVID-19 make up only a small fraction of currently reported cases, but the CDC wants states to do a better job reporting them. So what are they and why do they matter? We took a closer look to help reporters and members of the public better understand this complex COVID-19 metric.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Amber Wojcek is a B2B marketing director in Sanford, Florida, and a contributor to The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Tracking the States and the CDC

lede.lede: For months, we've worked to patch together inconsistent state-reported data into a national set of numbers for COVID-19 case, death, and testing in the US. The CDC has now published a COVID Data Tracker, but their data only partially matches the numbers we get from the state public health authorities. So we took a closer look.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Position Statement on Antibody Data Reporting

lede.lede: As antibody tests become more widely available across the United States, we call on all states and territories to preserve the integrity and usefulness of their COVID-19 testing data by maintaining separate viral testing and antibody testing counts.

Specifically, we track the difference each day in the value of total ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/coronavirus-testing-basics"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"PCR tests","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"—what Texas calls “molecular tests”— completed, as reported by the state ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://txdshs.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/0d8bdf9be927459d9cb11b9eaef6101f"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"on its dashboard","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". This calculation results in the same value as the state reports for “Daily Molecular Tests” on other pages of the dashboard, though the state reports it visually as a seven-day average, as we often do.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Since August 2, this daily tests number has plummeted. Although the state was averaging more than 60,000 new tests per day at the end of July, that number fell by half by August 12. The state then reported a record number of new tests on August 13, which we’ll cover more later. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"At the same time as Texas’s decline in reported tests, the state’s reported number of COVID-19 cases has not declined nearly as much. As a result, the state’s official seven-day positivity rate—calculated by dividing new cases by new tests—has shown a steep rise, peaking at 24.5 percent on August 12 before dropping in a single day to a still-high 16.1 percent on August 13. A nearly 10% fluctuation is unexpected for any seven-day averaged value, but especially for something as important as the positivity rate.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"x5a9OekHlpcCWUtFNo2GB","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The other data we compile from the state, however, doesn’t seem to support the narrative suggested by such a precipitous rise in positivity rate between August 2 and 12. New cases have declined, although some of that fall could be explained by a reduction in testing. But the number of people with COVID-19 who are so sick they require inpatient admission at a hospital has fallen steadily from its late-July peak. Declines in both cases and hospitalizations suggest that the outbreak in Texas is easing. But as outbreaks slowed in other hard-hit states, such as New York and Arizona, we saw positivity rates decrease, not increase, as has happened in Texas. So what’s going on in Texas? Is the state really completing dramatically lower numbers of tests, or are we seeing some kind of reporting problem?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"3x8Yrq3OdX9ynbyFa4IDEQ","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Tests pending assignment","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"After closely reviewing ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://dshs.texas.gov/coronavirus/additionaldata.aspx"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"the downloadable data files the Texas DSHS publishes","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", we have concluded that the number Texas reports for total cumulative tests conducted is the sum of two figures: the number of tests it has matched to counties ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"and","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" another field for tests that have been reported to the state, but are not yet assigned to a county. (You can find ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://github.com/ckelly17/Covid-Tracking-Project/blob/master/TX%20Testing.Rmd"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"the code we used in our analysis here","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".) The state calls this category “pending assignment.” ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Between August 2 and August 13—a date range coinciding with a DSHS systems upgrade—the number of tests in the “pending assignment” bucket plummeted. Then on August 13, the state added a net total of 85,542 tests to the “pending assignment” category, resulting in the state’s largest single-day increase in reported tests. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://twitter.com/wesrap/status/1294084516626206725?s=20"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"KXAN in Austin has reported","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that the August 13 influx was the result of correcting a coding error at a major hospital.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This correlation between new total tests and tests “pending assignment” has led some ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.statesman.com/news/20200811/covid-19-testing-falls-in-texas-but-spread-continues"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"journalists","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://twitter.com/therealarod1984/status/1293303173638168582?s=19"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"observers","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" to the conclusion that something in this transfer of tests from the “pending assignment” category to the various counties is leading a large number of tests to be ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"thrown out","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", not merely assigned to a county.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6uOmQVjrhki7Qix2YSjUaz","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As you can see in the chart above, over 100,000 tests were removed from this category on three days in the last week, part of a large drawdown since August 2. The state then ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"added","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" over 85,000 tests to \"pending assignment\" on August 13, the same day the state reported its largest ever daily increase in tests.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Importantly, the downward pressure on the state’s testing numbers produced by drawing down tests \"pending assignment\" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"may","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" be counterbalanced if ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"all","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" of those tests are assigned to counties—but that may not be happening.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The chart below shows the number of new tests reported by the state at three levels: ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"all reported tests (what we report as our topline number for the state)","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"tests pending assignment, and ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"tests attributed to individual counties. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"ordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"First, the number of ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"total ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"new tests reported has declined dramatically(blue). Additionally, the number of new tests ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"attributed to counties","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" has skyrocketed (green), reaching a seven-day average of over 120,000 on August 12. If you only looked at individual counties, or took the total of all individual counties, it would look like Texas was conducting more COVID-19 tests than ever. The true story is somewhere in the middle. Compared to the end of July, the daily number of new tests attributed to counties has increased, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"but not by as much as new tests \"pending assignment\" has decreased (orange)","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"—this raises the question, are all the tests leaving \"pending assignment\" being accounted for? Ultimately, what we see is a plummeting ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"total","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" new tests reported figure and suspicious fluctuation in statewide positivity rates.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"7ECT33Rkc1g20TyQtWMZ8W","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"As you can see below, in Bexar, Dallas, Fort Bend, Harris, and Tarrant Counties (the five counties with the greatest number of tests reported to date), the number of new tests reported has increased dramatically since the end of July. This creates a phenomenon in which positivity rates at the individual county-level are decreasing, while they are increasing at the state-level. However, it is unclear whether the “new” tests assigned to counties are really new tests or whether they are simply older tests being reallocated from the previous “pending assignment” designation.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"4uQrmtrA7beKeHSfqc1vkl","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To complicate matters further, when Texas reported a record number of new tests on August 13, it actually lowered the seven-day average for new tests in four of the five counties shown here, as the majority of these new tests were added in the \"pending assignment\" category and not associated with a county at all.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Our main question","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":": has Texas been dropping some of the tests removed from \"pending assignment\" from the cumulative statewide count, or are they all assigned to counties?","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" The former would mean that the recent slowdown in testing may be in part a reporting artifact, rather than a real decline. If the latter is true, it means that all recent ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"county-level","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" data may be unreliable—as are the gating criteria/metrics used by local governments, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/hidalgo-county-health-officials-school-reopenings-15478720.php?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=HC_DailyHeadlines&utm_term=news&utm_content=headlines"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"schools","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.tmc.edu/coronavirus-updates/covid-19-testing-trends-for-greater-houston-area/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"health systems","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that are built from these data—because it appears that many of the “new” tests assigned to counties are actually from a backlog of tests \"pending assignment\" that may include tests from weeks or even months ago.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"New systems","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This analysis is also complicated by the fact that DSHS ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://dshs.texas.gov/news/releases/2020/20200731.aspx"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"moved to a new electronic test reporting system on August 2,","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" designed to “enable incoming lab results to be processed faster.” This new system, whose adoption coincides exactly with the beginning of the changes we observe, could be responsible for the recent swings in \"pending assignment\" tests and new daily tests. As the number of total tests stored in \"pending assignment\" is reduced—it is currently at 476,276, down from more than 1.1 million at the beginning of August—we may find that the number of new reported tests begins to normalize and align better with our expectations. Right now, however, the system is erratic, and movement of tests into and out of the \"pending assignment\" bucket seems to be causing huge swings in the state's topline testing numbers and confusing the public and health authorities alike.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"What Texas can do","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Testing and positivity rates are a crucial tool used by states and localities to assess the trajectory of the virus in their area. Right now, the data reported by Texas DSHS—both statewide and at the county level—is unusable for that purpose. While a period of disruption when working through a backlog might be understandable and justified as DSHS moves to a new system, communication from state authorities has been lacking. Unlike","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/six-months-into-pandemic-washington-still-struggles-with-covid-19-data/"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":" other states","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that have experienced electronic reporting issues and been forthcoming about technical challenges, Texas is not saying anything about why these changes are occurring or whether the data is accurate. There had been no official communication from state authorities until August 13, when Gov. Greg Abbott ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-13/texas-governor-says-positivity-rate-surge-under-investigation?utm_campaign=socialflow-organic&utm_source=twitter&cmpid=socialflow-twitter-business&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"noted in a press conference","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" that DSHS was bringing in a “special data team” to","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.star-telegram.com/news/politics-government/article244877182.html"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":" investigate the rising positivity rates","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", but he did not bring any additional clarity to the situation beyond ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.rev.com/blog/transcripts/texas-gov-greg-abbott-press-conference-transcript-august-13-coronavirus-update"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"suggesting that testing demand has declined","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To start, DSHS can answer some fundamental questions about their data:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"What is the technical definition for tests that are \"pending assignment\"? In a statement to the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Texas Tribune","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" on August 13, DSHS clarified that situations like incomplete addresses lead to tests being categorized this way until further research is done to determine which county to assign them to, but more information on how these situations are dealt with is needed.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"What is the process by which tests are moved from “pending assignment” to individual counties?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Are tests ever removed from \"pending assignment\" but not attributed to a county, thus decreasing the total number of tests conducted statewide? ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"If so, how many, and why have they been removed (e.g., duplication, antigen/antibody tests, non-residents)?","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"ordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Due to its size and its substantial COVID-19 outbreak, Texas plays a major role in our nationwide dataset. We’ve seen ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://twitter.com/COVID19Tracking/status/1293310516513763330?s=20"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"testing decline at a national level","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" in recent weeks, and the apparent testing decrease in Texas has been a big part of that (though not the only culprit). Texas should be ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"increasing","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" testing to suppress its outbreak. Along with this, the public—and officials throughout Texas—needs a full explanation for the behavior of the positivity rate curve in recent weeks, including an explanation of which tests are recent and which are from weeks ago. Without transparent documentation of what is really happening with testing in Texas, the state’s data remains too murky to rely on for decision-making at any level of government.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

references.caption: Texas DSHS positivity rate calculation as of 8/12/2020

image.title: Auto-uploaded image (1) at 2020-08-14 17:08:14
image.description: Screenshot of the 16.08% positivity rate for Texas from the DSHS dashboard.

image.title: Auto-uploaded image (6) at 2020-08-14 17:08:16
image.description: Graphs of tests (sharply falling), cases (falling), hospitalizations (falling), and deaths (falling slightly) for Texas, all data available at https://covidtracking.com/data/state/texas.

image.title: Daily change in number of "pending assignment" tests
image.description: Chart showing the daily change in the number of "pending assignment" tests, showing small additions and subtractions of tests from this category until August 2, when a series of increasingly large subtractions took place, followed by a single large addition on August 13.

image.title: New tests by reporting type
image.description: Chart showing new tests by reporting type, with tests attributed to counties rising sharply from August 2 till August 12, then falling; tests pending assignment falling sharply from August 2 to August 12, then rising; and total reported tests falling from August 2 until August 12, then rising.

image.title: Daily tests in select TX counties
image.description: Chart showing daily tests in select Texas counties, all of which have maintained an overall rising trend since April 2.

lede.lede: According to the official state numbers, COVID-19 testing has dropped dramatically in August. However, county-level statistics show the opposite story. What’s going on?
